prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG-01
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarimetric observations in B3 of the 14 PACO faint sample sources with S(20 GHz)>200 mJy in the "field 1".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are interested in polarimetry, then we rely on the single continuum setup selection: for our purposes, the suggested standard frequencies for band 3 are enough.

The sources have been selected as being point-like in the AT20G survey which means that they fall within the survey synthetised beam of about 10 arcsec at 20 GHz. At high frequencies the emission should be dominated by the most compact regions, hence we expect that our target sizes fall well within one third of the ALMA band 3 primary beam, or are point like also for the ALMA resolution.

The science goal includes the polarimetric observations in B3 of the 14 PACO faint sample sources with S(20GHz)>200mJy in the "field 1". By using data provided by ATCA observations in September 2014 (see the Science Case file), we have extrapolated the spectral behaviour for each of these sources from frequencies between 5 and 40 GHz, up to about 100 GHz. We expect a minimum flux density of 28 mJy at 100 GHz. Since the source which corresponds to the minimum is undetected in polarization, we have assumed for the fractional polarization a lower limit provided by the minimum fractional polarization extrapolated for a detectable source (up to 100 GHz), i.e. about 1%, which turns out to be consistent with minima measured by Trippe at al. 2012. Hence, we expect polarized flux densities >0.28 mJy and a sensitivity limit of 0.05 mJy should give >5 sigma detection both in total intensity and in polarization.
The observation of all the targets, the calibration, and the overheads for SG1 and SG2 sum up to about 3.4hr, that is below the indication of the OT of 6hr. We are aware that the latter arises from the need of a 3hr session to obtain a proper leakage calibration, considering independent leakage calibrations for each SG. If our project is not considered extremely time-consuming for this reason we can rely on the standard system-defined calibration. However, we consider that, given the closeness of these 2 SG source positions, they can share the leakage calibration. If SG1 and SG2 target sources are observed in sequence with the same leakage calibration they can be observed in about 3.4 hours. We think that merging the calibrators observed in the 2 SGs will allow us enough calibration for our purposes.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG-02
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarimetric observations in B3 of the 9 PACO faint sample sources with S(20 GHz)>200 mJy in the "field 2".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are interested in polarimetry, then we rely on the single continuum setup selection: for our purposes, the suggested standard frequencies for band 3 are enough.

The sources have been selected as being point-like in the AT20G survey which means that they fall within the survey synthetised beam of about 10 arcsec at 20 GHz. At high frequencies the emission should be dominated by the most compact regions, hence we expect that our target sizes fall well within one third of the ALMA band 3 primary beam, or are point like also for the ALMA resolution.

The science goal includes the polarimetric observations in B3 of the 9 PACO faint sample sources with S(20GHz)>200mJy in the "field 2". By using data provided by ATCA observations in September 2014 (see the Science Case file), we have extrapolated the spectral behaviour for each of these sources from frequencies between 5 and 40 GHz, up to about 100 GHz. We expect a minimum flux density of 21 mJy at 100 GHz. Since the source which corresponds to the minimum is undetected in polarization, we have assumed for the fractional polarization a lower limit provided by the minimum fractional polarization extrapolated for a detectable source (up to 100 GHz), i.e. about 1%, which turns out to be consistent with minima measured by Trippe at al. 2012. Hence, we expect polarized flux densities >0.21 mJy and a sensitivity limit of 0.04 mJy should give >5 sigma detection both in total intensity and in polarization.
The observation of all the targets, the calibration, and the overheads for SG1 and SG2 sum up to about 3.4hr, that is below the indication of the OT of 6hr. We are aware that the latter arises from the need of a 3hr session to obtain a proper leakage calibration, considering independent leakage calibrations for each SG. If our project is not considered extremely time-consuming for this reason we can rely on the standard system-defined calibration. However, we consider that, given the closeness of these 2 SG source positions, they can share the leakage calibration. If SG1 and SG2 target sources are observed in sequence with the same leakage calibration they can be observed in about 3.4 hours. We think that merging the calibrators observed in the 2 SGs will allow us enough calibration for our purposes.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG-03
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Polarimetric observations in B3 of the 9 PACO faint sample sources with S(20 GHz)>200 mJy in the "field 3".

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We are interested in polarimetry, then we rely on the single continuum setup selection: for our purposes, the suggested standard frequencies for band 3 are enough.

The sources have been selected as being point-like in the AT20G survey which means that they fall within the survey synthetised beam of about 10 arcsec at 20 GHz. At high frequencies the emission should be dominated by the most compact regions, hence we expect that our target sizes fall well within one third of the ALMA band 3 primary beam, or are point like also for the ALMA resolution.

The science goal includes the polarimetric observations in B3 of the 9 PACO faint sample sources with S(20GHz)> 200 mJy in the "field 3". By using data provided by ATCA observations in September 2014 (see the Science Case file), we have extrapolated the spectral behaviour for each of these sources from frequencies between 5 and 40 GHz, up to about 100 GHz. We expect a minimum flux density of 12 mJy at 100 GHz. For the faintest source in polarized flux density we estimate ~ 0.1 mJy at 100 GHz. Hence, with an expected polarized flux densities > 0.11 mJy, a sensitivity limit of 0.03 mJy should give >3 sigma detection both in total intensity and in polarization for the faintest object in the sample and >5 for all the other targets.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose ALMA Band 3 polarimetric observations of a complete sample of 32 sources of the faint (S(20 GHz) > 200 mJy) PACO sample (Bonavera et al. 2011), in the Southern Ecliptic Pole region (ecliptic latitude < -75 dec) to estimate the radio-source contribution to the CMB polarisation power spectrum at 100 GHz in total intensity and polarisation and, by complementing the low frequency observations already obtained with the ATCA, to characterize the polarisation properties of radio source populations up to about 100 GHz.
